sentence: Investors adjusted positions in Coca-Cola and Procter & Gamble yesterday, giving the stocks more time to rebound from long-term lows.
optionMONSTER's tracking programs detected the purchase of 9,722 July 85 puts in PG for $3.15 and the sale of an equal number of August 85 puts for $3.95 yesterday.
Some 10,175 July 42 puts in KO were bought a few minutes later for $0.76 and comparable selling took place in the August 42 puts for $1.19.
In both cases, volume was below open interest in the shorter-dated contracts.
This suggests that the traders had previously sold the July puts to collect the premium but found themselves underwater after the shares declined.
Rolling forward by a month generated an incremental $0.80 of premium on PG and $0.43 on KO.
Now they won't be forced to buy shares at the strike prices Friday.
(See our Education section for more on the potential benefits and pitfalls of put selling.)
KO fell 0.10 percent to $41.13 yesterday, and PG rose 0.13 percent to $82.15.
They're down 3 percent and 9 percent respectively in the last six months despite the S&P 500 rising 6 percent in the same period.
Similar activity appeared in home-security stock ADT, which has fallen sharply on the heels of a poor earnings report in April.
This time, traders bought back 4,286 July 35 puts for $2.40 and sold 4,286 August 35 puts for $2.80, resulting in a net credit of $0.40.
All three companies issue quarterly results during the August expiration cycle, so those put sellers are betting that they won't fall much on the news.
Overall option volume was 17 times greater than average in ADT, triple normal amounts in PG, and double the usual in KO.
